payload.title: Arriving at CDG & Orly
payload.description: Paris transport has undergone a massive modernization. The 2024 Olympic legacy remains, most notably the direct rail links to Orly which have replaced older, slower bus routes.
payload.criticalAlert: The **Entry/Exit System (EES)** is now active for all non-EU travelers. Expect 15–30 minute delays at immigration for biometric registration (fingerprints/photo) on your first entry into the Schengen Area.
tips: **Metro 14 (Orly):** Forget the OrlyBus. Take Metro Line 14 directly to Châtelet or Gare de Lyon. It’s fully automated, runs every 2 minutes, and costs only €14 (or is included in a Navigo pass).
**RER B (CDG):** This remains the fastest way into town from CDG, but it is notorious for strikes and pickpockets. If you have heavy luggage, consider a flat-rate taxi or an app like G7.
**RoissyBus Warning:** As of March 2026, the RoissyBus from CDG to Opéra is being phased out. Check the RATP app for the latest bus alternatives or stick to the RER B.

**ETIAS:** If you are visiting in late 2026, check if the **ETIAS** (European Travel Information and Authorisation System) has officially launched. It will require a €7 pre-travel digital authorization.

payload.title: Digital Ticketing & Navigo
payload.description: The era of the 't+ cardboard ticket' is officially over. Everything is now digital via physical Navigo cards or your smartphone.
payload.criticalAlert: Do NOT attempt to use old paper tickets. They are no longer sold and may not work in turnstiles. You must use a **Navigo Easy** card or the **IDF Mobilités app**.
tips: **Smartphone Entry:** Most Android and iPhones (iOS 17.5+) can now act as your Navigo card. You don't even need to wake your screen to tap in at the barriers.

**Validation:** You MUST validate your ticket/phone at every entry. Inspecting 'contrôleurs' are frequent on the Metro, and they do not accept 'I didn't know' as an excuse for an unvalidated ride (fines start at €50).
**Navigo Liberté+:** If staying for more than 3 days, this 'pay-as-you-go' digital system is the cheapest option for locals and frequent visitors, billing you at the end of the month.

payload.title: Scams & City Safety
payload.description: Paris remains very safe, but 'opportunistic' theft has shifted from pickpocketing to high-tech 'phone snatching' during the digital transition.
payload.criticalAlert: Phone snatchers on e-bikes often target tourists near Metro exits or café terraces. If you are using your phone for navigation, keep it firmly in both hands and away from the street-side of the sidewalk.
tips: **The 'String' Scam:** Common near Sacré-Cœur. Men will try to tie a 'friendship bracelet' on your wrist to demand money. Keep your hands in your pockets and say a firm 'Non, merci' while walking.
**Metro Door Alert:** Do not use your phone near the Metro doors when they are about to close. Thieves often grab phones and hop off just as the doors shut.
**Restaurant Bills:** Service is always included (*service compris*). Tipping is not required, but leaving €1–€2 is a nice gesture for exceptional service.
